description:
This is your classy "kitty bar."  It's where 21 year olds learn how to drink alcohol in a social setting.  You can also tell it's a kitty bar because all the young un's in this bar are having quite coherent conversations despite the unnecessarily loud level of noise from the music the play.  Way too loud.  Why does the volume have to be on 10?    Still, there is one part of the bar where you can breathe the rushing outside, foggy San Franciscan air off of Grant Avenue.

The bartendress was fairly friendly by San Franciscan standards.   The beers weren't too over priced and they had a decent selection.  I had a couple of Coronas and she even remembered to include a lime.

Not bad.  The crowd here are ironically very innocent looking.  At my age, I felt as if I walked into a G-rated movie with a bunch of little children, wearing make up pretending to act like adults.

I swear to you, the people here are too young.  I think the City of San Francisco should change the drinking age to 40 and over.
author: Tony U.

description:
This was the spot during the nineties.  I must've gone there at least 50-60 times.  The place had a great vibe with a mix of regulars and non-regulars, the drinks were cheap and they stayed open late.  I lived closer to Union Square but had no problems making my way (even walking) to North Beach for this S.F. drinking mainstay.  It was one of those places that was popular but not trendy.  I remember my friends and I lamenting about the changing demographic in SF during the Dot-Com boom of the nineties.  We were glad to see that The Savoy and not been completely invaded by the techy horde.  There were some, but thankfully most stayed away (no disrespect intended to those in tech).  

It's funny how history repeats itself.  With the current tech-boom changing the SF landscape once again, I was surprised to see how quiet the bar was on a Saturday night.  A friend and I arrived right when they opened and stayed there for a few hours.  I told that the place would probably get going after 10:00 pm.  By the time we left after 11:00 it was only half full.  It could have filled up later, but it didn't seem like it would.  One of those party busses that looked like a cable car stopped right in front.  About thirty drunk and loud, but happy folks stepped out and entered the bar.  

I read some reviews that The Savoy had closed down for a while and then reopened.  I'm not sure if this was why they weren't busy on warm Saturday night, but it did feel different.  I loved that place and wanted to take my friend there.  Alas it was not like it was, even though it looked the same.  But it was quiet enough so that we could talk and have a few drinks.  I'd go back if I was in the area.  

One small thing, as another reviewer mentioned, they do need to clean their beer taps.  My pint of Stella was sour/stale and I switched to mixed drinks.  Not sure of the joint is under new ownership/management but that should never happen.  My advice to them is get that handled.  A good bar still, but you only serve drinks, don't screw that up.
author: Rich H.

description: Best bar in San Francisco. Enough space to avoid sharing oxygen with the riff raff and yuppies, but compact enough to where you still feel like you're with the *it* crowd. There's 2 separate bars, tables to bring your own food and eat at, pool tables and enough eclectic decor to play a different game of eye spy every time you come visit. You can get no-frills cocktails and take them over to San Francisco's hidden gem of a dance floor, complete with disco lights and lasers. -1 Star because they recently revoked their policy of play your own music on the bar speakers, and Javier, the neighborhood friendly bartender, no longer works there. But that still won't prevent me from starting the night off at Savoy anytime I'm in North Beach. Put your name in at Tony's down the street and head here to pass the time while you wait. You can't miss it.
author: Mark D.

description:
Savoy Tivoli has an owner who cares about customer concerns and an amazing atmosphere, unique for San Francisco. After expressing my displeasure with a specific bartender not honoring a happy hour deal, the owner was quick to resolve the situation and was quick to re-educate his staff on the importance of quality customer service.

While at the bar on a Saturday night (around 10:30pm), me and a group of friends were sitting at a table and I offered to go buy some drinks. A friend had asked for a glass of white wine so I went up and purchased two glasses of wine. The total was $16 and I tipped $3, all cash. When I came back to the table, we were just chatting and my friend asked if I got the deal on the wine. What deal? My friend pointed out the main reason she got a glass of wine was because it was supposed to be $5. Looking around, there was a promotion being promoted on pretty much every table in the bar. "All glass of wine - $5, 8pm-12am."

Seeing as the bar wasn't too busy, I went up and told the bartender who served me that I hadn't received the deal. He said the promotion was not going tonight and that it shouldn't be on the table. I asked for a refund of the difference and was denied. I then asked if a discount or small pour of another drink could be given instead to make up for the difference. The bartender said he could not provide anything cause "the boss is watching on the security cameras." The bartender at the Patio bar who said his name was Javier would not admit a mistake on behalf of the bar and would not apologize for the false advertising. I asked to speak with a manager and was refused by Javier because the boss was "on the roof" and would not come down.

I asked if he would at least take the other deal placards off the tables so as to not mislead other customers and he said he was too busy (there was nobody waiting to be helped during our conversation, but there were people sitting/standing at the bar with drinks). I asked if this is really how little they care about customer service, and at that point, he may have apologized saying there was nothing he could do.

By going around Javier, I was finally able to get in touch with the manager/owner. He was very receptive and offered my refund and a much more personal and friendly experience on my next return.

Aside from this one bartender, Savoy Tivoli is a very special place for San Francisco. For those of you looking for a unique atmosphere, this is the place. The open patio in the front is a pretty cool space. It's like an indoor patio with large, open windows that is amazing on a nice night like when I was there. It reminds me of sitting at a cafe patio in Italy or Spain and is great for a relaxing drink after work or before going out to dinner in North Beach.

I will be back.
author: Danny P.

description: Legendary bar in ''Nbeach''  been around since 1906 and I have been coming here since 1989!! Cool spot to grab a pop and people watch. Also fun during annual North Beach Festival!!
author: Sean K.

description:
Our friends were looking for a chill option on a crazy, beautiful night when the Giants were playing on TV and  they ended up at Savoy Tivoli. We joined them after dinner and we didn't really know what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised to find our friends sitting in this awesome indoor/ outdoor patio area in this very chill spot on Grant Street. 

The place was perfect for a warm city night to have some drinks and conversation without normal indoor voices. I always appreciate it when places aren't too loud. We only got beers - I wouldn't say the place looked known for  cocktails. 

Quickly the spot filled up with folks getting drinks before going out for a wilder night and that was our queue to leave. The place is surprisingly large. In addition to that indoor/outdoor with plenty of seating, there was a back room with a pool table, another seating area, and then a whole dance floor and other side with a giant bar. It makes me curious to know what the place is like as a dance club...
author: Veronica L.

description: Seems like a good bar, but the bouncer was openly belligerent before a word was spoken or a drink was poured. I'd skip this place until they hire new people. I wanted to live this place, but the door guy made it impossible.
author: Clay G.

description: There is no other establishment like the Savoy Tivoli in San Francisco! Great atmosphere and people in the very best of North Beach! Enjoy this unique space that's been in SF since before the 1906 earthquake!
author: Leesa K.

description:
What happened to The Savoy?

This was THE SPOT back in the day.  It was always completely packed every weekend.  So much so that we north beachers would actually make sure to avoid it.  

This was the birthplace of Beach Blanket Babylon.  The first run was here, before they got the Club Fugazi space a couple of blocks away.  

And despite being predisposed to being overrun w tourists, euro trash, & people that could not hold their alcohol, The Savoy was still an institution.  It was still a place I was sure to bring my girlfriends when they came to visit from out of town.  That was the thing w this place; we avoided it, but we still respected it.

There was a big problem w noise a few years back.  Apparently, several neighborhood residents complained & complained.  I never understood this.  If you want peace & quiet, then you shouldn't move near a bar.  Common sense, right?  They were temporarily shut down.  So, consequently, today they're only allowed to have live music for a very limited amount of hours a month.  Sad.

It's all about that front patio.  Totally romantic, sexy, & european.  It's still to this day a chronic movie scene to be sitting on this patio, wearing a slinky dress, sipping a cocktail.  Preferably while smoking a cigarette.  Think "A Streetcar Named Desire."

The mystique is still here.  It has that cafe swank & dive bar thing down.  The patio for the former, the second barroom for the latter.  

It would be great if the Savoy could pick itself up & be a player in the hood again.  The history & the space deserve that.

I know I'm not the only one that misses it.

3 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: This WAS the best bar in San Francisco because they would let you play your own music BUT it is no longer. The owner changed the rules and now it's super boring. They don't let people in past 1:15 and they don't let you play your own music. I'm not sure how they'll have business ever again? Because if there are no good throwbacks to dance to, then this bar sucks. The bartenders are nice because they agree that this bar used to be fun, but the owner doesn't know what fun is.
author: Sarah S.

description:
The SAVOY TIVOLI is a must visit, once you do, you'll want to go back. I found that this page's details are incorrect. If your going to visit you need to know:

****MOST IMPORTANT-- YOU CAN PAY WITH VISA AND MASTERCARD!! They've seen the light! HALLELUJAH It's no longer a cash only bar!!  Can I get an AMEN!

 The hours have been changed. The bar is now open only Thurs. Fri.,& Sat nights.

 Thursday's- 8:00 PM to 11:59 PM, unless busy then 'til 2:00 AM . 
 Friday's- 800 PM to 2:00 AM
 Saturday's 8:00 pm to 2:00 AM

THEY NO LONGER SERVE FOOD. However, we went to NB Pizza and brought in a pie! We were told that The Savoy allows anything other than beverages to come in from the outside, even delivery. It's really cool to have an appetizer, dinner, or dessert on the heated Open Air Indoor Patio, looking onto the street, while enjoying a cocktail from the Bar that's right on the patio.  How cool is that!
author: P.I. M.

description: Door man is awesome and very friendly, nice vibe and they have heaters by the windows. THEY TAKE CREDIT CARDS
author: Jennifer R.

description: I wish I could give zero stars. Worst bar in the whole  city.  Staff was rude and horrible. Not coming back.
author: Preston H.

description: Beautiful open air bar with nearby art galleries. Beautiful colors decor and pool tables!!!
author: Ioanna I.

description: Love the ol Sav. Great spot any day of the week. The bartender, Javier, is the heart of the whole institution. 5 stars.
author: Jake M.

description: Best old school bar on the north beach that bar running from 1906 so it's old but gold they got plenty big place full bar, pool tables, dance area a lot of room in there if you guys love vintage go there
author: Azatbek S.

description: I stopped in for a draft beer and realized they need to clean their taps. I asked for a different beer and it too had the taste of lines that had not been cleaned in awhile. I suggest getting  cocktail instead. I was disappointed because I liked the layout and feel of the patio.
author: David F.

description:
Don't come here if you expect a 16 ounce pint, at least today but maybe every day. The boss has them pouring "pints" into 14 ounce plastics cups ( they say "14 ounces" on the bottom ) to take advantage of tourists here for the North Beach Festival.
We ordered pints of Lagunitas beer for $6, already not cheap. The plastic cups they poured us looked small, but the bartender insisted they were pints. So we paid and drank them. I was thinking of asking the bartender to fill one with water and pour it into a pint glass, when my friend found the "14 ounces" printed on the bottom. We pointed it out to the bartender and he said, "They must have changed it." I don't think the International Bureau of Weights and Measures has changed the measurement for a pint.

Oh, and the bartender tried to grab $3 from under my forearm when I wasn't looking, but I'm going to chalk that up to inexperience. Really? A $3 tip on a $6 14 ounce pint? Bold!

Anyway, go somewhere else and get a real pint, 16 ounces, of lagunitas for $5. Or just quit drinking for awhile. It's a waste of money anyway.
author: Nick B.

description:
I've only lived in North Beach for 6 months now, but I've managed to visit Savoy Tivoli a handful of times, the first being before I even signed a lease to live in SF. 

Apparently there is plenty of history in this bar.... it was opened in 1906 and has survived earthquakes, fires, and political drama.  

Honestly, I'm surprised that this bar manages to stay open.  It always appears to be dead when I bring out of town visitors here.  It was so dead that I walked in and back out right away the last two times I had guests with me.  The bar just appeared to be a little "lame".  

The "vibe" of this place is awkward and kind of creepy.  I can't put a finger on what kind of patrons visit this place-- are they tourists? Folks from the nearby hostels?  Townies? There's a random dance floor playing modern music and then a mix of throw-back historical fixtures.  What exactly is Savoy trying to convey?  Pick a genre and run with it.....

I must say though,  I love the open-air indoor patio deal that opens up to Grant Ave.  

This bar is cash only, so come prepared!
author: Andrea H.

description: Awesome place to listen to jazz on a Saturday afternoon!!! Great band and nice crowd. The cocktail waitress we had was very out of touch with her job, but she was nice enough. My biggest bummer is that it's a cash only bar. Cash??? That's crazy.
author: Sandra P.

description: Like the outdoors/indoors feel. Super open to the patio area which is also heated. There is pool (change machine was broken but bar helped us out) and a jukebox (bar turned it off to play their own music after we had put money in). It was super empty and the music was too loud for the volume of people, we had to shout just to hold a conversation. Overall, okay.
author: Sarah S.

description:
As this place is literally half a block from my place, our apartment and associated friends frequent this place quite a bit. 

Big fan: $1.25 pool tables, drinks happy hours until 10pm, foosball table, space heaters, and of course tvs to watch Lakers games.
Downside: live bands that interrupt wonderful afternoon naps. Just kidding, the live band is amazing and y'all should definitely check it out.
author: Linda X.

description:
I want to really love this place since it is pretty big and has pool tables and plenty of seating that is directly near open windows.   There is also a cool little picture booth that costs $3 for pics.  

My only bad thing I have to say is that they do not take credit cards and are cash only.   They had a swiper thing but said they only took cash??? I don't know if they only do that for the late night crowd but it makes it a hassle.
author: Eric K.

description:
I don't know why I haven't review the ST, Savoy Tivoli yet.
This is my school era hang out.
I still remember very vividly, September 1981,  I was with my room mate, even though we were so stoned, by Thai-stick, walking upper Grant Avenue on one sunny Saturday afternoon, ended up the ST, sitting at the balcony, drinking corona, watching and making fun of people for hours, eating NB pizza cross the street. I had 4 corona and 5 slices of pizza after a big burrito lunch at a Mexican place on Columbus Street, so as my room mate. We were so high and drunk, we must look so stupid Japo-ass, laughing for anything moves for all day, omfg!
I don't think I told the story to my sons yet, should I? I don't know.

I remember that the NB pizza was so filthy back then, I saw so much cockroaches in there, but, none of us cared. Also, the Mexican place on Columbus Street, now it calls Taqueria Zorro, but in 1981, we saw 3 Korean guys were making burrito! So, when we were ordering, we were trying really hard not to laugh, because why 3 Korean guy doing burrito? 

Btw, the last Saturday, I was here with my gf and 2 other friends, I did not know that there was Mal Sharpe's Big Money in Jazz Band at the ST.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wASavZmeD8c

Malcolm Sharpe is an American television and radio personality with roots in San Francisco, California. In the early 1960s, Sharpe teamed with Jim Coyle to create a series of comic on-the-street interviews for San Francisco radio station KGO.
Take a look, this is Mal Sharpe's San Francisco!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=058yFfpZFg4

Mal Sharpe's San Francisco?
Hell Yes, He was the best!
What's your favorite fish?

The ST is still my best in SF.
Btw, my favorite fish is Saba.
author: Nobu K.

description:
3.5 stars.

I like this place a lot.  It reminds me of San Diego where the bars are open and big!  I like that there's so much seating, more than one bar, that it's spacious, that there are games to play... but it's cash only.  Womp womp.  Still not used to living in SF!

It's close to a bunch of other bars, but sometimes it can be hard to get an empty cab, which is why I hate going out to North Beach (aka in fear of not being able to find a ride home). 

During the day time, they sometimes have a jazz band play, which is relaxing and just reminds me of summer time!  If I were to come back, it would be during the day.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Okay.... I've only been here on a Saturday afternoon between 4-8pm but that experience easily earned the 5 stars! 

We had wandered over to North Beach and were looking for a place to grab a drink or dinner.  As we walked down the street we heard this incredibly jazz trumpet playing somewhere up the block.  As someone who grew up around jazz musicians, it sounded too good to be live so I just assumed it was a bar that had their doors and windows open.  As we approached Savoy Tivoli it was this AMAZING and LIVE jazz band playing right inside the restaurant with all the windows open and a lively (and very diverse) crowd of people enjoying the music.

This band consisted of between 5-7 older men (like 70+) who seemed to have played together for years.  These guys were UNREAL. Not only were they totally entertaining the crowd with their funny stories from playing in Boston jazz clubs in the  50s and 60s but these guys possessed a raw talent that I have not seen in a long, long time. I was sitting there in awe thinking how lucky I felt to have stumbled into this bizarrely wonderful scene in the middle of North Beach on a rainy Saturday afternoon.  

So moral of that story - GO ON SATURDAY AFTERNOON and pray to god that you see this wonderful group of men perform.  

As for the venue - weird place.  Looking at other reviews it sounds like it's a pretty happening bar later in the night?  I did see the sign advertising $2 shots... 

It's a pretty large space - includes pool tables, two LARGE bars and plenty of tables.  The bartender (bald guy....forget his name) was fantastic.  We gave him barely anything to work with (except for a "something less sweet than a Manhattan") and he made our cocktail dreams come true.  Not to mention this guy was being incredibly friendly to some tipsy older women (looked like the jazz band groupies) and manning the bar himself effortlessly.  We were almost tempted to ask him to sit down with us just cause he looked like a cool guy. 

All in all, this is one of the best SF experiences I've had.... the live jazz was just a scene on its own and something I'll definitely try to revisit again soon.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Yeah, at the end of Grant street, far far away from the other bars...it MUST be good. But it's not. Its a decent place to hang out if you're looking for a really quiet night, but if you're going to Northbeach instead of the dive down the street...are you really looking for a quiet night??

The first time I came here was for my birthday. Rolled in with a crew about 20 people deep, mixed guys and girls. We became the entire crowd. What intrigued us was $3 shots until 11PM. Forreals!? Selection wasn't crap liquor too: Grey Goose, Fernet, Jamie. All my liquors were here! The amount didn't seem like a full shot, but for $3 bucks each, its not bad. 

I like it as a quiet spot to start the night out with really cheap liquor. Other than that, there's not really anything pulling me to this place.
author: Lily W.

description:
Disclaimer:  I BARELY remember being here.. but I will write about the things I do remember :)

It's mostly an older crowd.  The music was loud.  The patrons were more on the "let's relax and hang out" side versus the "let's get CRUNK TONIGHT!!" side.  There was a football table and two pool tables.  

Oh, and $2 Jamesen shots on Firday night until 12am. 

...

Now you know why I don't remember anything here. :)

It was a Friday night, and it wasn't too crowded.  I love sitting towards the front because they have huge windows that open up.. kind of gives the place a pseudo-outdoor feel.  Since it's in SF, it does get cold.. but they have heat lamps everywhere, so we stayed nice and cozy.

Despite all the good things I've said about this place, it's still just 3 stars because the overall flow of this bar just didn't fit me.  It was kind of dark and sticky??  I know those are two very different adjectives to describe a place, but I can't think of any other way to describe it.  The football table was old and all the pieces felt disgusting.  It's almost as if beer had been spilled all over the place, but it wasn't cleaned thoroughly enough... does that even make sense?  

Overall, this probably isn't a place I'd stay at all night.  I would probably just grab a drink here and then move on to something else.
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Oh the Savoy.  I keep getting older, and you stay the same.  Actually, that isn't quite true.  Have they always had a dance floor and I just never noticed?  Or is that a new thing?  Not sure, but on the Saturday night I went there was a single man dancing.  By single, I mean, one person... jamming by himself.  Get your groove on sir, get your groove on, I say.

We ended up here around midnight after getting kicked out of the Church Key (hey, it closes at midnight!?!?!?)  It was crowded, but we still found a table at the patio area.  Yay for heat lamps.  It wasn't that hard to get a drink either.

The most exciting part of the evening was when the bouncer refused to let to underage kids into the bar and the kids start swinging punches at the bouncer.  It was crazy!  They actually managed to rip the sleeve off of his jacket.  

All in all, when you find yourself in North Beach and are looking for a bar, the Savoy is good bet.
author: Chloe M.

description: I was waiting for a table at a restaurant in North Beach, so I was looking for a place to get a quick drink. Savoy Tivoli's open patio was very inviting on that warm night. We had their house margaritas which were great. It's usually hit or miss with the margaritas, and they definitely hit it.
author: Emmy Q.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend and two friends as we waited for a table at a nearby eatery on a Saturday night. 

Good, dive-y ambience in the front. Towards the back there are pool tables and separate room with more space and a dance floor. The place was empty when we were there. However, they have very very inexpensive beers! Cash only but there are ATMs nearby. 

Would recommend and come back!
author: Siv L.

description:
Fun spot with good drink specials.

This was the 5th stop on the pub crawl and it was definitely a goody! A large bar and plenty of patio seating. Friendly bartenders who serve up the inexpensive libations quick made this place shine for me. I will return next time I am in North Beach. Cash only sucks.

Did I mention they have cheap drinks?
author: Justin C.

description:
It's funny... when I started this review on my phone, I had five stars penciled in and raved about Henry the bartender. 

Then, Henry served my friend a vodka and sprite instead of a vodka ginger ale, told my friend he could go f*** himself if he didn't like it, and charged him double for the trouble. 

By the end of the experience, we had a choice between our friend getting arrested for capital murder or sticking around to see if the owner would fix the problem. We decided to err on the side of caution and leave. 

Henry was probably the worst bartender I've ever see, and this place sucks all kinds of rotten eggs.

Never, ever, ever go. 

By the way, management, this incident was last year. I never finished the review because my adrenaline was running high and yelp fell down my lists of priorities that night. Fire Henry. The bar was relatively cool without that psycho pouring drinks.
author: John S.

description: This is a cool bar, except the security and management are total jerks. We went to a birthday party here where they told us we couldn't stop by to say hello outside. The patio faces the sidewalk, so when we pulled up with our stroller (and baby, who was sleeping because it was 5pm) they pulled a huge fit, and told us we were "blocking the sidewalk" (note: we were 100% not blocking a single area of the sidewalk) and had to leave. Even after ordering a coffee, the security guy informed us that "we could sneak vodka into that coffee, because that's what he used to do." Obviously he has never taken care of an infant and been awake for 900 hours and doesn't understand that you need coffee at all hours of the day. I found the lack of accommodations for this place super annoying considering we weren't even in the establishment and only passing by outside. There are a lot of places in San Francisco where the homeless set up their "quarters" to settle in for the night, and I felt like the fact that we were merely a couple stopping by to say hello to friends and then asked by security AND management to leave, in comparison to how many places have the homeless sleep in their stoops each night, we were such a minuscule issue that we really didn't need to be asked to leave. Especially at 5pm. Super disappointing. I'll suggest my friends go elsewhere from now on. We stopped by Tupoli just a block away after we left and were greeted with loads of friendly service.
author: Sarah S.

description: Hear ye, hear ye! The Savoy Tivoli is open on Sundays! I found this out last Sunday when I was strolling Grant Ave. I'm always happy to see this place open so crossed the street to see why it was open...there was no one there except the bartender and door man. Obviously I went in - a chance to have the place to myself! The bartender and door man explained the trouble they've had in the past with a neighbor's complaint about live music. So, while the situation has been solved by not having live music, the place is still wonderful and needs people to enjoy it. Check it out! Great staff, great place, great beer selection, and great music (the bartender was playing some sick house music when I was there.)
author: Sandy C.

description:
this is my go-to place for waiting for a table at don pisto's. the bartenders are fun and good to chat with, and the drinks are decent. very open area.
and to the bartender there: sorry you didn't get to hear my "vomit in japan" story... some other time.
author: Xander C.

description:
I love this place.  

When I feel the need to stop for a little seat in tourist central and grab a quick espresso prior to agreeing to walk my good friend down to the wharf for a little sea lion action, Savoy Tivoli offers solace for anyone seeking to stay away from chains of mass destruction.  

I'm pretty generic when it comes to caffeine.  I am not a regular cup of coffee person unless I'm forced to, otherwise café lattes run the gamut.  And if the baked items look delectable enough, then I'll purchase the occasional muffin or buttery pastry.  Keep everything simple. And Savoy Tivoli does this effortlessly with the colorful backdrop and clientele that keeps me well immersed in observation.

Lots of room, enough for a group of friends, grab your cup, lounge, and watch the world pass by out front.
author: Miika M.

description:
My wife and I met here on our first date.  We sat on the patio, talking, drinking a couple of pints, sheltering under the heaters in the cool March air.   Later that night, we walked down Grant Street and had a wonderfully romantic dinner at Viva's.

So you hate the frat boys and the pseudo blonde tramps walking around this place?   F**k 'em... Why don't you just grab yourself a pint or some other elixir, put a dollar in the jukebox, play some tunes, maybe shoot some pool, or just relax and enjoy.  You're in San Francisco, in North Beach, in a cool bar that's been around a hundred years, before the beatniks were even born!   Just enjoy it, baby....    There you go, it's all good.
author: David O.

description:
This is a great spot tucked back in North Beach to grab a drink and just sit a spell. I love the atmosphere and the charm, and the collection of "lady lamps" is rather impressive.

They also have pool tables with ample space to show off your skillz, or, in my case, lack o' skills. I've also walked by when they have a Jazz band throwing down tunes, so keep an eye out for that as well.
author: Greg S.

description:
I was having a night out with my friends and we were bar hopping in the area; this bar was one of our stops.  The place has a good amount of pool tables/things to do other then just sit around and drink.  But even if that's your thing, they do have plenty of tables to go around.

The bar area can get pretty tight and the bartenders aren't very nice ... not to mention that it's CASH ONLY.  It isn't a place I would think about going to first for bar hopping or to stay at an entire night, but it is a good place to stop at in the middle of your bar hopping fun.
author: Pia V.

description: Security guy didn't let me say hi from the outside to my friends inside patio just because I was with my baby in the stroller, then he asked me not to approach to the entrance with my coffee. Big time discriminate against mothers and babies. Awful place. Please don't give your business to people like that. Manager same kind...
author: paulina o.

description:
Let me start by saying when I went to ST, it was SantaCon, therefore I have been told that the experience I had there is not the "usual" and it was much more crackin' than normal...

.. but either way, I had a great time. We secured a table in the back corner, right by a creepy statute and the dance floor: PRIME people watching spot and it was awesome for getting out of the rain.

The bar has a laid back casual feel, it's sorta open to the outside which was nice because it kept fresh air circulating, and they have heaters so don't worry about being cold.

Aside from a ton of Santas everywhere, be prepared to have cash, that is important as they don't take anything else.
author: Katie K.

description:
Just had a beer and shared some company in the back.. I didn't even order my own beer but the bartenders looked like a lot of fun.  

Great chill atmosphere.  I'm going to make an ass- (out of) U & ME here and say the live music on Saturdays 3-6 transports you to NoLa.. I've never been to New Orleans hence the "ass making"..

Bathrooms were a little trashed but whatever it's a bar and there was soap and water.. Much higher standards than some other late night estabs I've been to!

Oh and there's billiards for you folk looking to shoot something.
author: Casey A.

description: Stopped by Savoy for a friend's birthday.  I'm a sucker for open indoor patios and pool tables, so this place gets a thumbs up from me.  Decent dive bar for a chill night with friends.
author: Emily W.

description: Very fun! Great atmosphere, friendly waitstaff, great time.  Jason (bartender) and Ruby(security) made it fun and memorable. Jason makes the BEST martinis and keeps the evening fun and lived.  Great place
author: Robin B.

description: I can't speak for late nights, but for a roving band of ladies looking to kill time on a Friday night around 7:30 this place is great.  Got a large table right away in the outer area, the bartender made me a drink that I concocted and was nice about it, and you can watch everything happening on the sidewalk from the comfort of your table with drink in hand!  It started to pick up around 9:00 (natch) and we were on our way by 9:30....but I know I could sit there all night and watch the scene.
author: Laurie H.

description:
Absolutely worst bar in N. Beach. I came here once in a hurry to use the ATM and the woman behind the bar WOULDN'T LET ME unless I bought a drink. WTF? I'm 99% sure they make money off the ATM machine anyway and either way, it's just a dick move to deny someone the use of the ATM when they need cash and are in a hurry. It's no skin off their nose. 

But that's just their worst offense. Their day-to-day consists of overpriced drinks, terrible atmosphere and zero redeeming qualities. 

Avoid like the plague.
author: Chris K.

description:
***Good***
Very chill. Decent drink selection. Pool table.

***Bad***
Cash only. Not a lot going on here.

***Recommendation***
Bring cash.
author: Nick K.

description: The 3 stars is for the atmosphere and the nice bartender. I love the open space in front, unique decor, pool table and dance floor area. Casual fun place BUT drinks were pretty bad. One of my friends ordered a specialty drink and it tasted horrible like Chinese medicine. My drink waa way too sweet. And yes Cash Only, that's fine if they had a ATM machine but I didn't see one. We went on a Wednesday night it was ALL men and just us ladies, hey that wasn't a bad thing haha.
author: Karen T.

description: Cute. Open outdoor seating area. Plenty of space. Couple of pool tables, dance floor. Very feisty and flirtatious male bartender working on a Friday night.
author: Sonya Z.

description: 2 Pool Tables ($1.25/game), 1 Foosball ($1.xx/game/7balls), and an amazing Long Island Ice Tea (the best my friend has ever tasted) = the perfect combo for a chill Friday night.
author: Hanna L.

description:
Friday night. 

$2 Jameson shots. 

I'm home.
author: O'Shea J.

description:
"Mal Sharpes Big Money in Jazz Band" caught the ears of my fiance and I as we walked down grant street. These guys sounded phenomenal. We stopped outside, and listened for a while. We had a decision to make. Either we needed to get the car from the metered spot and leave or go feed the meter and come back. We we chose to get the car and leave... initially. 

Then we decided that was too much fun so we turned around and came back to Savoy Tivoli's. I ordered a Cabernet and it was delicious. I ordered a Shirley Temple for my fiance. All together that was ten bucks plus whatever I tipped. 

Tivoli's is a fun little bar, that plays live jazz on saturday afternoons. It's not pretentious like some spots in SF and not "divey" like other spots. The price was right, the drinks were good and the music was fun. Can't wait to spend another Saturday afternoon there. :)
author: Jarred D.

description:
This place is a terrible business.  They sell the most watered down mixed drinks in IKEA cups.  Seriously, it was nearly all soda in my drink.  They also charge you $6 for half ass beers on tap in 10oz mugs.  I'd rather just walk in and get slapped then walk out to save me the trouble at this horrendous bar.
Worst of all? The bathrooms look like the Loma Prieta earthquake started at the faultline between the urinals and the toilets resulting in the most crooked and foulest smelling bathrooms this side of TJ.
author: Joey S.

description:
First of all, it's so hard to walk in here and look at that giant monstrosity of a pool table sitting where those darling booths used to be a million years ago.  But my ambivalence about the Tivoli is more current.

Pro:  They showed Mrs. Peskin that she's not the only one who can grease a palm at City Hall.  And they have the balldacity to post an article about her failed attempt to close the business (which has been around since the beginning of time, despite the fact that the noise bothers her transplant ass) on the wall in the ladies room.  I like the chutzpah.  Also, they have an outdoor patio.  

Con:  I only go here when it's empty, so I won't bother complaining about the chode coterie that shows up on the weekends.  But this is the smallest cocktail I've ever seen.  Did they special order these glasses from the Lollipop Guild??  And each thimbleful of vodka soda will run you $7.  So basically, this business thinks their clientele is retarded.  Urgent Message to Management:  WE'RE NOT ALL AS DUMB AS THE PESKINS.
author: Rosie W.

description:
This was our kick-off spot before we started bar hopping around on a Saturday night. $2 Jameson Shots? Yes, please!

The bartender was pretty chill and friendly and we had a great table facing the streets, which allowed for ample people-watching while I enjoyed my gin and tonic. Only downside is that the bar is CASH ONLY. There is an ATM nearby, but it is definitely a hassle if you aren't prepared.

If you want to get your groove on then you'll be very disappointed with Savoy. It was pretty dead with people just standing around, talking, and awkwardly shuffling their feet. 

Aaaaand that was our signal to head out.
author: Vinh N.

description:
Cool space but lame drinks. I seriously think my drinks was a glass with a bunch of ice cubes with a splash of  lime. Actually, I dont "think", I am "convinced"....Hmmmm...

Thank goodness for awesome friends....I guess as they say, it is about the company not the place. Totally true this particular night! We had a great time despite the lame drinks.
author: Rachna P.

description:
Three stars seems pretty par for the course for Savoy.

There were 5 of us sitting on the patio. We were ordering 7&7's all night. They do make a pretty good 7&7 here. I'll give 'em that.

PROs:
+ Bartender was cool.
+ Patio seating is nice.

CONs:
- CASH ONLY.
- Empty dance floor was a bit off-putting.
- Atmosphere isn't great.
author: Dalton C.

description: The weekend jazz is one of my favorite SF experiences for a lazy yet lively weekend afternoon.  Kids aren't allowed, and we now have a toddler, but it's open to the street and fun just dancing along in the streets.
author: Mr. S.

description:
So the pool tables are slightly tilted, but they have $3 Rolling Rock and the tables are usually open and relatively cheap, unlike many of the other places around North Beach.  Good place to come with friends on a weeknight (when it's nearly empty).  You can stare at the walls plastered with art of varying quality and talk at a level that is not going to make your throat hurt and your ears ring the next day.  

I love walking by here on Saturdays--you can hear the jazz from three blocks away, and there are always people hanging out on the patio.  It can get a little crowded on weekends, and people here on weekends aren't usually that interested in meeting new people, since it's so easy to hang out in a big group without speaking to someone outside said group the entire night.  But overall, I like this place, especially the popcorn, which does a particularly good job of soaking up the beer.
author: Sydney H.

description: Another of the rare surviving San Francisco classics. It surprisingly roomy and a fun bar to hide out whether you're at the cafe tables open to the street (all too rare) or hunkered down in back near the pool tables.
author: Clay W.

description: Savoy Tivoli reminds me of a bar in Tijuana: plenty of space, randomly filled with different areas: one with small tables, an area with pool tables, an area with neon pinpoint lights strobing, small wooden dance floor with black lights in a corner and multiple bars that never seem to be that busy at 9pm. The one nice/saving grace is that the bar is fully open to the outside giving it a patio experience. Too bad its normally cold in SF, but isn't that what the drinks are for: to warm you up? I would give this place 3 stars but I was mad that with 2 TVs in the bar, they wouldn't turn one of them the Warriors game. Instead the bartender said his manager is only letting them play some cheesy Charlie Chaplin movies on TV. Good thing we asked about changing the channel before I ordered. His answer of no, made me bring my business down the street to Gino and Carlo's.
author: Rachelle T.

description:
This place was barely tolerable back when you could smoke cigs on the patio, but of course you can't even do that anymore. I guess the cigarette smell interfered with the scent of piss and stale beer.

Last time I came here was on a Tuesday after work with a friend. Not a single other person in the bar. Two Buds for $12. On a Tuesday. 

Possibly the biggest ripoff in an overpriced neighborhood.
author: Mike S.

description:
We roamed up and down grant twice and weren't satisfied with any of the other bars. The night started to seem like a disaster until we stumbled upon this place. We went inside and started with a round of $2 Jameson shots- how great is that?!?!?

Pros:
-$2 Jameson and Fernet on Friday and Saturdays
-lots of seating, great to just hang out
-decent ventilation (not stinky or stuffy like other places)
-friendly, non-douchey crowd
-spacious, so you don't end up getting mashed into strangers like other bars
-juke box, pool tables
-nice waitress
-patio seating
-its a little loud, but you can still hear your across the table
-funny little awkward, empty dance floor area. it's kinda funny to look at the 3 or 4 people who end up dancing there (funnier when buzzed)

Cons:
-bartender takes a while
-doesn't really bother me, but heads up, it's cash only
author: Jennifer C.

description: Came here on a Saturday night and the place was dead! There's a little dance floor area with disco looking lights, but that was empty as well. The bar had cool lantern looking lights and the drinks were cheap (margarita + $2 beer + whiskey 7 = $14!) Only thing is it is CASH ONLY.
author: Emily C.

description:
Pretty chill place, but not the beat crowd at times. Not as bridge & tunnel as some of the other infamous north beach spots. 

Great selection on the juke box if I'm remembering correctly, and the outdoor spot is pretty nice to sit out at. But, unless you go at the right time, it won't quite be relaxing in the patio, it can get pretty crowded out there on a good night.
author: Anish B.

description:
Beautiful sunny weekends in SF are so distracting for someone like me. I feel like a kid in a toy store - there are so many things to do, to see, to try...and my neighborhood, especially, makes it SOOOO difficult to focus! I can run on the Embarcadero and enjoy the breeze. I can walk up to the Coit Tower and enjoy breathtaking views and the fun little wild parrots. I can go to the park and people watch. I can go to one of the many cafes and enjoy a delicious cappuccino while reading some magazines. I can browse the nice interesting neighborhood boutiques. I can go to a poetry reading at City Lights. And now to add to the list, I found out that I can have a delightful lazy afternoon, listening to a fabulous jazz band in a very charming bar two blocks from my place. How can I get anything done?!?!

I had been to Savoy Tivoly a couple of times in the evening for a drink with friends. Let's just say, it's not my type of bar to frequent at night. I'm more of a wine bar type of girl. But the Saturday afternoon experience at Savoy was fascinating, and opened up a whole new world for me. I saw things that I didn't even notice the other times, like the beautiful Italian themed decor, the old-fashioned dark wood bar, the vaulted archways, the old jukebox, and the photo booth. They also had big TV screens playing Charlie Chaplin movies - couldn't have been more adequate!

The crowd was older and a mix of locals and tourists. Cash only bar. But the best part of all: the captivating jazz band consisted of a bunch of senior guys that play every Saturday from 3pm to 6pm. They play great quality music and they are very very amusing!

The 5 Stars go to the Saturday afternoons. If you visit - or live - in SF, and if you are into jazz, you MUST try it at least once! It's such a fantastic way to spend a lazy weekend afternoon with a fun group, with a partner (the old ambiance gives the place a romantic aura!), or on a date with your fabulous self. Just like I did. :-)
author: Simone W.

description:
Live Jazz!!!! That is the very reason for my 5 star review. They have fantastic live jazz on their patio every Sat from about 3-6. 
We happened to be at a shop across the way and we heard the jazz through the open door. I absolutely love jazz music, particularly classic and New Orleans style jazz, so when I heard that crisp trumpet sound waft through the streets, I was hooked. We went over, grabbed a table in the back between the bar and the open patio window, drank Chimay, and listened to the music for hours. They also get another plus for having a fantastic Belgian beer on the menu! 
Everyone was so nice, in particular the bartender, Scott. He was an absolute character with a bald head and handlebar mustache that always crowned his friendly smile. :)
I would definitely come here again!
author: Krystal W.

description:
a bit too bridge and tunnel for me. Drinks are cheap, but were a little weak to me, bar is cash only.

It's another bar where you'll stink like an ashtray upon exit and oh the plethora of striped-shirted boys.
author: Nikki M.

description: So Savoy Tivoli used to rock... but i went last night and it was dead... Saturday night at 12 should be prime bar hours... plus it's cash only now, boooooooo
author: Aarash Z.

description:
I really wanted to give 3 stars to this place, but the last two times I've been here, it's been practically empty and just lame. They have a huge nice patio which is nice, especially if you are a smoker and the drinks are so-so, better than average, but not by much.

I HAVE had a good time here, a real good time, and anyone can with the right crowd and group of friends, but lately it's just been sub-par, and I would say it's not worth going out of your way.
author: Nate E.

description: Decent bar near the Grant & Green scene. It's good for grabbing beers with friends, but it's definitely your low-key option. Bring cash amigo, they don't take card.
author: Peter C.

description: I came here a few years ago and came back here on a saturday night. The place has not changed much. It gets crowded and pack later on in the night, but the drinks were decently priced, with waitress on staff. There's plenty of room, but as the night proceeds on, it gets overcrowded. There's two pool tables and costs 4 quarters, but the machine seems to always be broken. The security guard kept passing gas and we were downwind of it. Lots of beautiful women come here
author: Phan H.

description: Great dive bar with fun jazz music on Saturday. Totally dark and red on the inside. It's the kind of place you could sit and drink all day in. I'd definitely go back--especially for that music.
author: Stacie M.

description: Super packed on a Saturday night. Went here for a girlfriend's birthday and it was packed. Although it was crowded, there were ample seats and drinks were easy to get. Pool tables and juke box are also fun here. Line for the women's bathroom was NOT fun. Great place to start off the night in NB.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
This is another one of those bars where I tend to run in to people that I potentially would rather not.  However, I usually overlook that and take the risk because of the great patio-like seating and fun atmosphere that Savoy offers up.  Some people will say it's just another Marina bar laid to rest in North Beach but I disagree. I find that the crowds here are much better than some said Marina bars ::cough Bar None:: 

There's tons of seating, it's spacious and it has pool tables and darts.  The major downside to this bar is that it's CASH ONLY. It's the most God-awful feeling when you're happily buzzed and ordering your next round of drinks only to figure out that your plastic isn't going to cut it.
author: Julia N.

description: $6 for a bottle of beer is really outrageous in my book. Last night, I bought four beers for $16 at the Ambassador. The Ambassador is a much classier place and I'd way rather spend $4 for a beer there than $6 at Savoy! I can't even use a credit card to pay for my beer at Savoy either!
author: Meghan P.

description:
Oh Savoy.

You and your little shot size cocktail glasses.  What's your deal? 

Why do I continually come back?  Well you happen to have a very nice clientele and I'm a sucker for an open air bar with a few pool tables. I've had many a good night with you and  luckily I drank before I arrived.

Here's a tip.  Most bang for your buck at Savoy is a nice bottle of beer.
author: Adam L.

description:
I had a hard time finding the place all the up in North Beach, almost missed the place when I went here first. But I like how the place is set up, nice cozy looking place with a cool patio area where you can smoke while sipping you drink.

 The bartenders were exceptionally friendly and made pretty decent drinks. however, the bar was cash only. They showed me where the ATM was but still there is that one word, Inconvenience. I thought the drinks were a little expensive but its ok.

They have neat pool tables where you can shoot a few rounds while listening to music from the jukebox and the crowd, it seems, is nice. Of course, you're gonna have a crazy hard time find parking in the city but this is a cool bar to kick it.
author: Sandeep R.

description: Went here on Santacon, and i understand it's a very busy day, but a male bartender was incredibly rude and passed over me multiple times. I'm so upset with my experience at this place that I don't ever plan to go back.
author: A P.

description:
ok - i like the Beatles and such but the juke box should be renamed The Beatles Box. I would have gladly purchased a dozen songs if there was better selection. Too bad. 

I like how there's a pool table in it's own sectioned off area so you don't have to deal with annoying drunk people walking by and getting in the way, which is inevitable at bars with pool tables. Still happens, but that's usually people you know and therefore it's more excusable. =p

Go here to drink - but not for music or dancing.
author: Cat T.

description:
Friends wanted to hear some music but unfortunately we only got to hear their last set for about 20-30 minutes.  

The band is good and lots of fun - friends enjoyed it so much, reminded them of New Orleans.  

The beer was a little colder than our last visit so some improvement.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I'm going to leave a very similar review to the other person who said that this review was more for Kyle (the bartender) than for the bar itself. 

The bar itself is nice, comfortable, whatever. it's ok. But Kyle made our evening. He made one of the most delicious cocktails I've ever tasted (called Friends of the People! Try it!) and had a story to go with each drink, and often each ingredient. Some of the ingredients and syrups were actually made by Kyle, on his own dime and in his own time. For someone who's only been bartending for a year, this guy makes getting a drink an experience. Really worth sitting at the bar and hearing his stories, infused with passion for mixology and history.

If he weren't bartending, the place would probably be a solid three stars.
author: Mez L.

description:
As far as space goes in the city, Savoy has one of the best. It has two rooms and two bars connected by an open doorway. There is ample seating and three pools tables that you can generally commandeer if you're feeling a little patient. The main bar has an open front that is great during those rare warm nights and plenty of heaters on the more common cold ones. 
The bartenders are a little forgetful and when it is crowded there are not even close to enough of them. This seems crazy because they probably have more actual bar square footage than 95% of other bars in the city and should be able to handle crowds pretty well.
Great for a chill Thursday night, but not the best on a sloppy Saturday.
author: Kenzie P.

description:
Do you LOVE overpriced drinks and a cash only bar? Do you love pool and photo booths? How about over-flowing toilets? If so, this is the place for you.

$18 for SMALL vodka sodas and a beer? Outrageous.
author: Misha F.

description:
Funny thing is, this is the third time I've actually been to this place but its so non-descript I couldn't remember a thing about it. For my next few reviews, I decided I am going to write them in the style of other Yelpers (who shall of course remain nameless).

__


Mr Tivoli: "Hey I've got a good idea - Lets confuse people into thinking our bar is somehow related to the Savoy in London"

Barman: "Yeeha. What a super awesome idea MrT".

Mr Tivoli: "Lets make them wait outside even though the place is half empty"

Bouncer: "Great! I get to pretend to be somewhat useful".

Mr Tivoli: "Lets charge exuberant prices for drinks, like $8 for Beer & $10 for Grey Goose".

MichaelH: "Yack! No thanks Mr Tivoli. Even Vesuvio scores more points than you since its cheaper and more entertaining".                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              


*Extravagant.
author: Michael H.

description:
i liked the outdoor seating, they had heaters which made it comfortable for you to sit out front, and nice to watch the people walk by while i have a relaxing chat over a drink with some friends.

I was surprised by how much room there is on the inside as well, and surprised to see a pool table, pretty cool.

The bathrooms were pretty grimy and i was there early in the evening too, so couldn't blame it on a drunk messy crowd.
author: Shadi N.

description:
I enjoy Savoy Tivoli for is laid back local bar action. Despite the peak bar hours, it never gets obnoxiously crowded. 

And well, I'm Japanese so I automatically like photo booths. [insert peace sign here]. I love the photo booth action for $3...bring home your very own Savoy Tivoli pictures! Aside from photo fun, they have several pool tables for a $1 a game. 

I have never failed to get prompt service here. The bartenders are quick, and they have a full bar including wine, and several beers on tap for roughly $6 (Sierra Nevada, Widmer Hef, Fat Tire, Peroni, and a few more from what I remember). There are also 2 bars to order from. The bathrooms are fairly clean with usually no long lines. 

I love the outside open awning patio. Great for perfect nights out in the city. The inside has plenty of seating everywhere, and several TVs with movies playing. I heard there's live Jazz music on Saturdays afternoons! 

Only drawback: CASH ONLY! Sometimes we just don't carry cash, why ST why not card...it's 2008!! Well, they have an ATM inside if you need cash.  

Well Savoy, I shall be back soon for some serious drinks, photobooth action, and an intense game of pool!
author: Catherine O.

description:
I am a big fan of photo booths (be it Japanese or not). My heart was won over on a Saturday night out in North Beach by a great little booth in the back room of Savoy Tivoli. Situated near the pool tables, this was the best $3 I spent all night. In comparison to the $6 beer in my hand, this was a deal! 

My pals and I got here a little early, around 9:30 or so, and we just beat the crowds of people. We were able to snag two tables in the back, which the others quickly filled up by 10. The bar was pretty fun. The line at the bar moved quickly and the bartenders were pleasant. Other than the expensive drinks, I enjoyed it.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Back in my younger years, we went to Savoy probably twice a month.  Its a great place to sit outside, smoke, and play drinking games.  

Side note- playing "I Never" while drunk with people who know too much about you while on a second date = no third date.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Went here last weekend with some friends after stopping (quickly) by the Lush Lounge. First, let me say as a non-smoker I was less than thrilled at the wafts of smoke coming into the bar. Yes, I am that type of person. But I have asthma so that gives me full griping privileges. 

Moving on...I love pool. I love it more than any other bar diversion. Well, imagine my surprise as I walked in to see, not one but, two pool tables! That sold it for me. Two seconds later I'm waiting for my turn to play. Of course, my three friends (all female) were excited as well (how could you NOT be?) and we started the game. ... 5 hours later four balls had been sunk -- two were the cue ball. Agony!  

Regardless of our sad attempt to play, we had a good time. The Savoy-Tivoli is a solid 3-star bar with pretty good drinks and a crowd that screams 'finished college now what?".
author: Ali L.

description:
I don't hang out in North Beach as often as I'd like because I'm always complaining that its "too far".  Now that's relative to my San Francisco guidelines as to anything over a $10 cab ride is just too far.  I primarily come out here when i "have to"..which sounds bad, and don't get me wrong, I appreciate the area, but truthfully id rather get drunk and be able to stumble home, not risk paying the cab driver too much money and looking in my wallet the next day not knowing if my money is in the cab drivers hands or the bartenders.  OK...so with that long drawn on sentence out of the way let me talk about this  bar.

When I "have to" come here, I do.  Whether it be for a birthday party, a reunion cuz a friend is in town, or we are dressed like Santa Claus running amuck in North Beach.  This bar has aspects I like, so i never am too whiny when told we are going here.  

Outdoor/kind of indoor patio.  Its covered, so you wont get rained on...sort of maintains heat, has a bar, is in the front so you can people watch, and best of all you can smoke your lil lungs out.  

One of the best photo booths in the city.  Yes, the photos say the name and address of the bar on them...but they are these amazing black and white shots, or at least they can be....that's right, they have options.  Everytime I go, I hoard the booth, take as many pictures as i can and stare at myself wondering when I got so damn good looking.  Then I look in the mirror and realize that this photo booth is magic.
author: Lauren F.

description:
This place gets no stars, but Yelp wont allow no stars so it gets one star for looking nice in the afternoon when it is closed.

Avoid this place unless you enjoy having drinks spilled on you by far-too-trendy 20-somethings with no manners or class.
author: Rob K.

description:
I seriously have to explore San Francisco more because until this week I had never been on the street where Savoy-Tivoli is.  Yes, 'tis a shame indeed... though I think coming here right before Thanksgiving was probably not the best time to try this bar out for the first time since there was no one there other than the bartender, another patron and the group of people I came there to meet.  

However Savoy-Tivoli does have everything a good neighborhood bar needs: plenty of pool tables, a foosball table, two bars, a photo booth and friendly bartenders.  And even though when I went it was empty I'll be back because it's always a good sign of a place when the bartenders tell you that they come in on their night off.
author: Natasha R.

description:
Cons:  I saw some guy doing a motorboat into some chicks boobs at the bar...at 8pm...uhh  1 star...gross.  I'm sure this doesn't happen every night, but that's the type of crowd you're looking at.

Pros:  
-Good music...4 stars for ELO and The Who
-Sexy location
-Pizza next door
author: Katherine C.

description:
I thought it to be a difficult question when someone asks, what is your favorite bar... Now I know and it isn't hard to say, Savoy! 

They have everything. Great crowds, pool tables, outdoor (kind of outdoor) seating, People watching spot galore, and cocktails!

Cheers!
author: Dee C.

description:
Remember all the popular kids from college; Chad, Melinda, Blaine, Chutney? Shatangi does and now I know where to find them. They still scream "Woooo" instead of saying "that's nice" or "I enjoy that". The drinks are well prepared and relatively inexpensive. It's fun to people watch on the patio. A well decorated lounge.

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
This one of those places that totally depend on how many people are there.  Sometimes its way too crowded and crazy.  Its super hard to get a drink and the bathroom gets really nasty.  

But then sometimes its awesome.  When its a little less busy and you can chat up the bartender.  Sit at one of the tables out front and people watch.  I think they have pool and some other fun stuff like a photo booth...again not fun when its super packed.
author: Angela S.

description:
I loved the layout of this spot. Some friends brought me here to enjoy a show that one of their friends was performing in. Definitely seemed like a local haunt for many, almost like cheers, because it seemed as if a number of people new each other. Or, all of the performers had their friends come and check out the show. Either way, it was cool. 

My only gripe was that even though I was inside enjoying the show, the open patio for smokers allowed for all the second hand smoke to waft in... I seriously felt like I was in "Gorrillas in the Mist" but with cigarette smoke. NOT Cool.
author: Anna S.

description:
Recommended for groups of friends who want a mellow spot to talk, play pool, and act stupid. 

Not the best spot to meet new people or for those who are offended by smokers.

Tip: remember to bring cash...no credit cards accepted
author: Jesse W.

description: I've always loved the Savoy for the laid back atmosphere and inexpensive drinks...  It's definitely a welcome change from some of the tourist traps on Columbus.  When I went to the Savoy recently, the crowd seemed much less laid back than I remembered...  But still, great place to hang out with friends.
author: Wendy L.

description: For a relaxing game of pool and kicking it causal with friends. And yes, that is a fake palm tree by the bar, but no you may not climb it or try to pick the coconuts.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Never too crowded. Great mix of people (mostly locals). Great location --- just on the edge of all the tourist-y spots. Very large place with pool tables and lots of seating! Cash only.
author: Lisa R.

description: I usually hit up Savoy before I go to Don Pistos right around the corner. Great atmosphere! Bartenders are super cool. Couple of pool tables in the back if youre down for a game. Always enjoy myself when I go. Overall great place to be!
author: Gustavo C.

description:
So I'm slightly buzzed (at best) upon arriving at Savoy on St. Paddy's day.  Needless to say, I needed a drink.  I roll up to the bar and, lucky me, I'm on the half of the bar that slow, sweaty, male bartender is serving.  I mean...I know he's not a hot girl, but I will tip you if you get me a drink, and I was in line for a huge order.  

The bar is crowded as hell, and, because male bartenders hate me (see my gbar review), he passed me by not one, not twice, but thrice (the third time he skipped from the guy next to me on the left, to the hot blonde directly on my right).  

So I speak up...hey buddy, wtf, you skipped me again.
Bartender:  hey, don't you dare talk to me like that.  I'm the bartender, how dare you swear at me
Me:  you skipped me...three times.
Doucheface: as he pours the girl next to me her drinks: you don't talk to your bartender like that, how do you expect to get served?
Me:  You skipped me, I'm not getting served anyway 
Doucheface:  Does anybody here think I skipped him??? (outloud to everyone in the general vicinity)

My buddy, the guy behind me, and the two girls to my right all raise their hands.  Bartender ignores the crowd response as he gently shoves a stick further and further into his ass.

(here, I consider walking away from the bar, but have invested about 10 minutes waiting for this tool to pour me a drink so I stay)   

Bartender finishes pouring drinks, walks back to me:  So...what do you say 
(he then proceeded to lecture me for about 20 seconds about the etiquette of kissing your bartender's ass before I interrupted)

Me:  Dude...it's St. Paddy's day.  The bar is crowded as hell.  All these people want drinks.  I want drinks.  Either serve me or don't.

Doucheface:  What do you want?

After the debacle at the bar and the ridiculous waits for drinks, my buddy and I decide to walk across the street to grab a bottle of beam, a sparx, and a coke.  So we mixed our own drinks.

Moral of the story...there really isn't one.  I just hate that bartender, and he puts on this whole dramatic show just to serve me and not get tipped.


Anyway.  Other than that...I like this place.  It's big, lots of seating, pool tables, alcohol. 

Three stars until I get confirmation that Doucheface no longer tends bar at Savoy.
author: I AM SOFA KING WE TODD DI D.

description: One star for the nice open space. Zero stars for rude service and watered down drinks. Who serves a Manhattan over ice and tries to convince you that that's just how they do it? Never coming back.
author: Queenie C.

description: This used to be a really popular place, so much so that at times it was standing room only. Then at some point it all switched and it became a really mellow place. Maybe the fifteen minutes is up. I've been confronted by paranoid pot smokers who thought I was "gassing" (whatever that means) them, seen midgets break up fights, women get their asses slapped by random people, amongst other things. You never know what you're going to get on a given night but every once in a while it's nice to sit outside and have a few Guinness when it's low key. It would just be better to be able to predict when that happens.
author: Kim N.

description:
I can see how this might get awful and crowded, but I definitely suggested that you stop in around 5pm on a cold winter Saturday. We found respite from the chill in the air and settled down under the heat lamps to some exceptional live jazz and a snugly Irish coffee (or two). We were with a large group where some played pool, some enjoyed the musicians and some just drank.  

ITEMS TO NOTE:
Live Jazz every Saturday from 3-6pm, 
Drinks are on the expensive side, 
There's a Photo booth ($3 for a set of 4 pictures),
This was Stop Number 4 on a birthday pub crawl, but I think I paced myself pretty well :)
author: Erin M.

description:
Don't know why but this place makes me think of New Orleans, even though I have never been there before. There's just a Southern, lively vibe to it without the crazy voodoo shit. I guess if SF ever celebrated Mardi Gra, this is where you would go to toss some beads.

The venue is pretty big place but it still gets insanely packed. The manager in the front seemed pretty disgruntled trying to shuffle drunk people along while the bartenders are hustling inside. Drinks are a little bit on the skimpy side; they use some tiny cups which get packed full with ice too. Overall, cool looking spot, not so cool drink sizes.
author: Ed L.

description:
One of the bouncers here went apeshit when my friend peacefully fell asleep with his head on the table because sake was evil to him during dinner.

I guess a few bullets here and there through the years at Savoy got their panties all in a bunch!
author: Faffy L.

description:
This place is not cheap and on the weekends it is definitely a scene. There are more bad things than good things about this bar but yet I've been here quite a few times. For smokers, it is fantastic because you can smoke in the entire covered patio in the front. They also have a pool table and a photo booth.

If the weather is warm it is nice to sit on the front patio but if you aren't a smoker you will still leave there feeling like you just chain-smoked an entire pack of ciggies and having to wash your hair and clothes.
author: Jackie G.

description:
While waiting for my friends to arrive, I spent half an hour by myself at this joint, scanning the room and watching old soccer high-lights.  It got me thinking.  Do I look and act like that as a man?  I certainly hope not.
Atmosphere is fine.  Two pool tables, sweet.  Digital Photo Booth, pretty freakin' cool.  Open indoor smoking patio, really freakin' cool.  Drink prices, not so freakin' cool.  Not so freakin' cool at all.
author: Max M.

description:
Savoy attracts mostly 20-somethings that could easily have gone to Bar None/Blue Light. Not that I have particular problem with that (hell, I think I fit into that demographic on occasion), but I was keenly aware of the multitude of "bros" staring each other down - perhaps in some primal ritual to determine who can claim superior brovosity.

My biggest beef with Savoy is the obnoxiously scientific and exact method of providing mixed drinks. Ask for any kind of cocktail, and they will pour exactly one jigger of booze into the glass before filling the remaining 90% of it with soda water, or tonic, etc. I don't know a ton of bars that actually measure out drinks like that, but pretty tasteless for a joint that claims to exude an "old-time" feel - I'm fairly confident that old-time saloons would at least top your drink off.

Savoy can be fun, but drink before going and stick with the beer, as it's the best bang for your buck.
author: Victor W.

description:
A spacey bar with interesting italian themed decor and warm orangey walls. Again it was cash another cash only bar. I had an absolute dirty martini. The drinks were overpriced. I think 19 for a round of 2 drinks. A martini and a well vodka rocks.

For a saturday the place was actually kind of empty. There was plenty of seating and it wasn't so loud u couldn't hear the other person talk which was a nice change from maggie's. Bartender was nice and helpful.
author: Aleyna S.

description:
We just happened to stop by here tonight, in the search of some place to hang out and just catch up with some visiting friends.  We were there early, so we had our pick of the seating in the outer area of the place.   Only problem was that sometimes the smoke from the groups sitting by the 'window' areas blew towards our table, but it was tolerable.  

Cool picture booth!  Dangerous if you're wasted though - evidence.  :)  Even though we didn't play, I'm always happy to see a pool table.  This is a fun place to enjoy with friends.
author: Denise M.

description:
I used to frequent Savoy when I first moved to the city - before I was 21.  Pre cell phones and CD's. . .you know the dark ages.  I had a fake ID and would be on the lookout for the ABC who would do random ID checks. . .

So it felt ironic to be at Savoy this past Saturday "of drinking age" and no longer a drinker of alcoholic beverages.  Certainly wasn't that much cheaper but, the ambiance is priceless - especially on a date.  Louise Armstrong tunes being played by a live jazz band, what more do you want?

Saturday afternoons there is a great jazz band that plays old tunes, they jam, they interact with the crowd. . .and it's free!  

The drinks are overpriced sure but the place is charming.  Savoy is an SF institution.  Don't go on a Friday or Saturday night.  The gem of the place is during the day when it's not too crowded.  They have a photobooth, pool tables, and a jukebox!

It's all about the ambiance.
author: James M.

description:
NOT A FAN.   I have been here twice and hated it both times.  Which really sucks because the layout of the place is so great.  But - 
a) it is way way too crowded, which I wouldn't mind as much if it weren't for  - 
b) said crowd is almost entirely made up of Marina transplants that are truly obnoxioius and insist on walking around with their pink collars popped and their plaid bermuda shorts hanging off their ass.  And that's just the guys.  Don't get me started on the drunk sluts. 

I sound bitter don't I?!?  Well, in general I am a lovely person - alas, I think this place just brings out the worst in me.  I must be growing up!  Anyways, maybe I will give Savoy one last shot on a weeknight, and then it will be relegated to the list of bars that get a Oh Hell No when somebody asks me if I want to go there (a la, Bar None).  Oh well, can't win 'em all....
author: A B.

description:
My best bud Dave & I went to Savoy Tivoli for a beer to kill some time before a friend's birthday party down the block. It was quiet & almost empty, despite being a Friday night. We sat at the bar, & were served by Victoria, who I'm nominating for Coolest Bartender I've Met In A Long Time (won't say ever, cause I've met some good ones, but she's up there). She told us about her crazy life in 1980s NYC/LA, gave us some awesome North Beach history, & was genuinely disappointed that neither of us are currently having any girl trouble, since her reputation is that of sage voice of female wisdom.

I believe her. And the next time the female perspective is needed in a bar setting -- for me or any friend of mine -- I'll be sure to put Victoria from Savoy-Tivoli at the top of the list.

A very spacious bar with old moldings...steeped in history, I'm sure. If these walls could talk...
author: Pete J.

description:
I used to come here a LOT back in the day. Most of my coworkers & friends lived near this part of North Beach and the Savoy was always big enough to accommodate the big groups we had since it had 2 bars, 2 parlors and an outdoor patio.

When SF banned smoking at bars years ago, this was one of the only options for places to go where you could still enjoy your drink AND a smoke while sitting on their patio. 

One of the major downsides was that it was cash-only. But it's been a while since I've been, so maybe that's changed...
author: John Eric S.

description: Honestly not a big fan of this place, maybe it's because this is a cash only bar or because it has this weird shape...dont know.  They have a few pool tables in this bar and many tables scattered around where most people just sit and hang.
author: Young N.

description:
I really like that this place has an open section to outside, but it's a double edged sword because then technically, people end up smoking in here...because really they're outside. It's huge- usually a table is open to sit at so it's chill...there are pool tables and good music...

I am leaving off a star because it feels a little Marina in there a lot of the time...I guess we're not far enough from the Marina to really think that won't happen, but still...
author: Diane S.

description:
I heart Savoy Tivoli! 

On the weekends, it's usually pretty packed, so I will really go into how great it is then...
- bartenders are attentive and awesome. They make great stiff drinks and if you ask them to get creative, they go all out!
- covered smoking porch is awesome, and there are a lot of tables to accommodate.
- there are two long bars, one in a no smoking section and one in a smoking section.
- TV on (nice to have while you wait for your friends)
- pool tables in the back (a buck to play) and a foosball thingy
- space: the layout of this bar is nice as you're not just in one big room. There are nooks where you and your friends can feel like you are in a more private environment, and I think that it adds a nice little coziness to it.

cons - 
- Bathrooms could be bigger.. Ok, so I was there with some friends last night, and every time I went to the bathroom for the entire several hours I was there, the left bathroom stall was occupied by the same person with black and white sneakers on. For hours. At first my friends and I thought that she was taking a really long dump, but after an hour and half, we were worried so we just started going to check up on the mysterious left staller... after no movement for several minutes, the feet shifted!! Scared of course (because it very well likely may well have been a REALLY long dump), we decide to venture out into the wild as honestly, that's just weird. 

Anyway, moral of the story is that if there is someone in one stall for hours on end doing god knows what, you only have one stall left in the ladies room and that kind of sucks.
author: Annie T.

description: It's my basic "meet-up" place for friends who have never been to the city. Or for going away parties. Or for someone's 21st, 30th etc. Def not a destination place for me but I have frequented this place many times. Besides overpriced drinks there really isn't much for me to complain about...
author: Amanda S.

description:
I love this place... when it is OPEN! 

You cant argue with a place that has such a fabulous indoor/outdoor seating area. Not mention I live in the area and it is so nice to walk by to see and listen to live jazz. When it's chilly they have heat lamps to keep you warm too.

Definitely a great weekday place to go grab a drink after work or after dinner. Watch out for the drunk corporate crowd though , oh and beware this place is sometimes closed during the week.
author: Nancy B.

description: Good place for groups, either hanging out by the open windows on the sidewalk, the two pool tables, the dancefloor or the two bars.  Two Dollar Jamieson Shot specials most nights til midnight,
author: Chet M.

description:
Cool Bar space.  But i really feel that they would make a larger profit off the investment of space if they got a DJ and made some sort of dance floor.  Alas...i suppose they're trying to keep a mellow feel where people just sit or stand around and chit chat (im more of a dancing lady myself)...and if they're really adventurist...play a little pool or Foosball
